content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find a restaurant in Boston that eats Boston lobster and asks for a rating of 4.6 or higher, and check out what a one-star review says.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/maps/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find a restaurant in Boston that serves Boston lobster, I should first search for "Boston lobster restaurant Boston" in the search box. The search box is element [0], and the search button is [1]. I will type my query into the search box.
Action: Type [0]; Boston lobster restaurant Boston
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: "Boston Sail Loft" in Boston has a rating of 4.6, meeting the requirement. To check out a one-star review, I need to enter the review section of this restaurant. I should click on the listing for "Boston Sail Loft" to access detailed reviews.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To read a one-star review for Boston Sail Loft, I need to access the reviews section from the restaurant's profile page. This can be done by clicking the "Reviews" button.
Action: Click [26]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Now the reviews breakdown is visible, with star rating filters on the left. To see a one-star review, I need to filter the reviews by one star by clicking on the "1" (one-star) rating filter.
Action: Click [36]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The interface has not changed from the previous step, indicating my last action may not have registered or displayed results. Since there are no visible reviews yet, I should scroll down within the reviews area to view the one-star reviews that should appear after filtering.
Action: Scroll [27]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: After scrolling, the visible area shows keyword/tag filters related to reviews, but still does not reveal the actual one-star reviews themselves. I need to keep scrolling in the reviews area to access user reviews, as they are likely below these keyword tags.
Action: Scroll [27]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: A reviewer's profile is now visible in the reviews area. To see the content of the one-star review, I need to continue scrolling further down to reveal the full text of Vy H.'s review or more details about the one-star review.
Action: Scroll [35]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible review shows a five-star review, not a one-star review. It is possible that the review filter is not properly set to show only one-star reviews, or I may need to scroll past the five-star reviews to reach a one-star review.
Action: Scroll [27]; down
Confidence: 0.96
Completion: 0.92
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible reviews still do not show any one-star reviews, nor any indicative text of a critical review. The reviews shown are still generally positive, and the one-star section is still not displayed. Therefore, scrolling down further in the reviews section is needed to find what a one-star review says.
Action: Scroll [27]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.95
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible review from Jessica Schlimmer is still another positive review, not a one-star review, as indicated by the visible text and absence of critical language. Since previous scrolls have not yet reached a critical or one-star review, I should continue scrolling down in the reviews section.
Action: Scroll [31]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.96
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The review area still does not show any text or visible review content, only images, implying reviews are accompanied by photos but not the critical one-star feedback needed. Clicking "More" may help load or expand additional reviews, possibly revealing one-star comments.
Action: Click [27]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.97
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current review expands to reveal meal type and price but remains a positive review, not a one-star review. To find a one-star review, I need to scroll further down within the reviews section.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.96
Completion: 0.98
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The review section currently displays only ratings for food, service, atmosphere, and wait time, all of which are perfect scores. To see a one-star review, I need to continue scrolling further down in the reviews section.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.99
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The review displayed now only shows photos related to the review and does not display any written one-star review content yet. The review area must be further scrolled down to access the text of another review, potentially a one-star review.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.995
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current review from Jason W is positive, and not a one-star review. The one-star (critical) review has not yet appeared, so I need to scroll further down in the reviews section to find a one-star review.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.997
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The area is still showing only images from Jason W's review and not written critical reviews. I need to keep scrolling down in the reviews section to move past image-heavy reviews and find any one-star (negative) review text.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.998
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The newly loaded review from Gabriel “Chuck” Hernandez is still a positive review and not a one-star review. Therefore, I need to continue scrolling in the reviews section to try and reach a one-star review.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.999

Thought: Only photos from Gabriel “Chuck” Hernandez's review are visible and there is still no one-star review text displayed. To locate a one-star review, I must continue scrolling down within the reviews section.
Action: Scroll [25]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.999
